instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.3V3_G3H: What is 3V3_G3H? This is one of the first power rails that must turn on for Macbooks that use USB-C for charging. This power rail powers the CD3215 chip that controls the USB-C charger, speaks to the USB-C charger, and requests 20 volts up from the default 5 volts that the USB-C charger puts out when initially connected to an unknown device. .
definitions.AVREF_SMC: What is AVREF_SMC? AVREF_SMC is a reference voltage provided to the SMC so that its sensors have a reference to work from, this should be 3.3v.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with shorted <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Liquid damaged <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board with 35立 to ground on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>. With plugged-in charger, I get 3.3V on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> and 20V.

When I inject 3V into <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>, the SMC warms up. Probably a shorted SMC, agreed?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with shorted <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Not really short, as you get even correct voltage.
But very low resistance for that power rail.
Do you note another hot spot on the board?

Check resistance to ground at <CAPACITOR>C5010</CAPACITOR>/21.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with shorted <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<CAPACITOR>C5010</CAPACITOR>: 4k立 to ground
<CAPACITOR>C5021</CAPACITOR>: 2M立 to ground

Hard to say if anything else heats up b/c the injection only draws 0.1A and I don't have thermal imaging.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with shorted <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: The machine actually starts in its current state, but runs super slow. Apple Diagnostics report SMC and PM errors (PFM006 and PPN001).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with shorted <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Very likely problems with trackpad flex/board.
Battery may be involved too.

Try first to disconnect battery and reconnect it after 10 minutes.
If still same problem, test with known good trackpad.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with shorted <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: I installed this board in a different, known-good topcase. Same issues: throttled performance and fan on high speed. <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> still 33立 to ground.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with shorted <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: BTW, machine runs at normal speed during SMC bypass.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with shorted <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Check <SIGNAL>AVREF_SMC</SIGNAL> voltage.

You may need to change the SMC.
Once removed, check diode mode to ground at <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> power rail.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with shorted <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP3V0_S5_AVREF_SMC</SIGNAL> is 3V.

I don't reball, so giving up on this board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with shorted <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Removed the SMC and short has disappeared (diode mode reading 0.350).

Do you have a suggestion on how to get started on reballing? Source for stencils and materials for  Apple boards?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with shorted <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
You can't reball a dead chip!
Do you think wooden foot massage helps for something???

Get another SMC from donor board, same model.
Aliexpress has necesary stencils for any kind of SMC.
Just do NOT buy flux there; avoid "chinese honey" use on repair process.

I personally reball with solder paste and direct heat stencil.
Many videos available on Internet; practice on scrap boards/chips...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with shorted <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Of course I was implying that I would get an SMC from a donor board.

Thanks for the tips on what tools to get. I'll give it a go!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with shorted <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Ok to use AMTECH NC-559 as solder paste? How do I know if a stencil is ok for direct heat?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with shorted <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Isn't that flux?
Don't buy flux on Aliexpress.
You can do the job even with cheap "chinese honey", but I don't recommend it at all.
I use ECOFREC TF49.

[URL unfurl="true"]https://es.aliexpress.com/item/4001223517824.html?gatewayAdapt=glo2esp[/URL]
You may find more sellers on Aliexpress.

I still use chinese solder paste.
Buy in small recipients 35-50g.
Not very expensive and much better quality here:
[URL unfurl="true"]https://es.rs-online.com/web/p/pastas-para-soldadura/1466191?cm_mmc=ES-PLA-DS3A-_-google-_-CSS_ES_ES_Herramienta_Electrica_y_Soldadura_Whoop+(2)-_-(ES:Whoop!)+Pastas+para+Soldadura-_-1466191&matchtype=&pla-338725996743&gclid=Cj0KCQjw54iXBhCXARIsADWpsG8__miVMrAH2tQpDODsVxmRkpUZf30PlJmbkxkuD-3qK4nNsT4fOQkaAjmzEALw_wcB&gclsrc=aw.ds[/URL]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with shorted <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Update:
Thanks for your advice. I now have a reballed SMC installed and this board is fully functional.
